Why Should We Care?

Neural networks are not a new invention. They have been around since Warren McCullough and Walter Pitts invented them at the University of Chicago 70 years ago.

What is new is their omnipresence:

In Industry

  • 22% of firms are aggressively integrating AI, 33% have limited implementation, and 45% are in the exploration phase.
  • AI is used for improving operations (56%), cybersecurity (51%), digital assistants (47%), customer relationship management (46%), and inventory management (40%).
  • The global AI market was valued at $136.55 billion in 2022 and is projected to reach $407 billion by 2027, with a compound annual growth rate of 36.2%.

In Education

  • 67% of teenagers have heard of ChatGPT, indicating a broad awareness of AI tools among youth.
  • Among those who know ChatGPT, 19% have used it for schoolwork, with this figure rising to 24% among 11th and 12th graders.
  • 69% of teens find it acceptable to use ChatGPT for researching new topics, 39% for solving math problems, and 20% for writing essays.

Given this widespread use, and the importance of tasks being delegated to this technology, treating neural networks as a “black box” is unacceptable. If we are to evaluate the capabilities and risks of this technology, we need to understand what is actually taking place under the hood.
